name: NewYorker
text: In her testimony before Congress, Janet Yellen expressed skepticism about the notion that promoting a vigorous economic recovery and taking strenuous measures to contain the coronavirus are in conflict. https://t.co/i7WJU0sePI

name: NewYorker
text: The Dance on Camera festival, now in its 48th year, will stream films including Susan Misner’s “Bend” and Khadifa Wong’s “Uprooted: The Journey of Jazz Dance.” https://t.co/90ipr667WE

name: NewYorker
text: Even Nixon seemed to understand that a President could not use his pardon power to erase charges against someone who might offer testimony implicating him in a crime, @JeffreyToobin writes. https://t.co/JchRK5Ah76

name: NewYorker
text: “By the time John Lewis made his exit from this realm, on Friday, his life had been bound so tightly and for so long to the mythos of the movement for democracy in America that it was difficult to separate him from it,” @jelani9 writes. https://t.co/Rff9MKqfaB

name: NewYorker
text: On a new episode of #NewYorkerRadio, two prison abolitionists argue that probation, drug courts, and electronic monitoring do more harm than good. https://t.co/tgnzW76xCx

name: NewYorker
text: Mustard now comes in dozens of varieties. Why has ketchup stayed the same? https://t.co/WsEEzuFVk7

name: NewYorker
text: Almost a century later, the ideas in “Modern Housing,” which argues that decent home should be seen as a public utility and a basic right, still burn. https://t.co/XEYnKQfdui

name: NewYorker
text: No criticism that John Lewis issued about President Trump was as strong an indictment as the simple facts of his life, @jelani9 writes, “born to Alabama sharecroppers, stalwart of SNCC, leader, exemplar of humility.” https://t.co/7MOHfaQ3DU

name: NewYorker
text: “I think that cinema was always so successful because it replicated this dream state,” Richard Linklater said. “Dark room, totally immersed. The lights would come up, and I forgot who I was for the last two hours.” https://t.co/0ZMF9YgPAy

text:
A new novel by the German writer Daniel Kehlmann places its protagonist in a deeply imagined early-17th-century world, a Europe ruined by the Thirty Years’ War.

name: NewYorker
text:
RT @jelani9: We’re confronted with the question of what exactly one does upon losing someone of John Lewis’s stature. The answer, he seemed to be telling us all along, is more of the same.

https://t.co/pqBO8niYIb

text: Susan Neiman, a philosopher who studies Germany’s confrontation with its Nazi past, discusses how the U.S. can reckon with its racist history. https://t.co/ReE39NMRTf

name: NewYorker
text: In Germany, researchers are working to track, record, observe, and quantify the spread of the coronavirus, aiding the government in efforts to study and contain the disease. https://t.co/0YSvECmFoh

name: NewYorker
text: “On reaching home, I immediately drove through the center of town and rejoiced at two remarkable sights: most stores were open, and everyone wore a mask.” https://t.co/lMA87mKo6M

name: NewYorker
text: RT @erinoverbey: Sunday Reading: Manhattan Sketches. My latest archive collection for @NewYorker is a selection of pieces on New York & city life—w/stories by Joseph Mitchell, Janet Flanner, Robert A. Caro, @susanorlean, Nora Ephron, Hilton Als + more. #NewYorkerArchive https://t.co/1SpMgoYrjm

name: NewYorker
text: “I think that we should all be activists,” @chancetherapper said. “I think that we should all be active in the dismantling of white supremacy and then creating a real heaven on earth.” https://t.co/sHZZ9QYG8d

name: NewYorker
text: “For the first time that I can remember, we’re getting TV about the Indian-American community unto itself, not about its struggle to assimilate,” @sanjenasathian writes, about the new Bravo show “Family Karma.” https://t.co/9gLx4R7kJy

name: NewYorker
text: The letters Virginia Woolf wrote after her brother’s death, in which she pretended he was still alive, show a writer experimenting, perilously, with fantasy’s transformative potential. https://t.co/3WKnpgyKAd

name: NewYorker
text: Peanut butter, the everyman staple, which contains neither butter nor nuts (peanuts are legumes), originated as a health food of the upper classes. https://t.co/OKpwRcJRGI

name: NewYorker
text: A 1971 profile of the jazz musician Charles Mingus. “My book was written for black people, to tell them how to get through life,” Mingus said. https://t.co/GUVwfYnNcw
